frameDefinitions: This frame covers words for Body_part(s) (BP) belonging to a Possessor (Poss), which may be characterized by a Descriptor (Desc).
This frame concerns people being in an altered mental state that is induced by an Intoxicant.
These are words describing basic commercial transactions involving a buyer and a seller exchanging money and goods, taking the perspective of the seller.
An Experiencer is in a State where a biological urge is signaling the need to perform a certain action such as eating, drinking, stopping exertion, sleeping, regurgitating, or having sex.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame describe an Experiencer who is feeling or experiencing a particular emotional response to a Stimulus or about a Topic.
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
frameExamples: He had to brace his right <t><fex name='Body_part'>arm</fex></t> against his leg in order to fight the roll.
Robin <t>sold</t> a car to Abby for $5,000.
Mr. Whiskers is <t>upset</t> that there are no more cat treats.
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
listRoleDefinitions: This Frame Element denotes the <fen>Possessor</fen> of the <fen>Body_part</fen>.
This Frame Element  is the <fen>Body_part</fen>.
The mental state of the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is changed by an <fen>Intoxicant</fen> .
The <fen>Intoxicant</fen> alters the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s mental experience.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes intoxicated.
The <fen>Buyer</fen> has the <fen>Money</fen> and wants the <fen>Goods</fen>.
The role <fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor or time, for example) which is exchanged for <fen>Money</fen> in a transaction.
The <fen>Seller</fen> has possession of the <fen>Goods</fen> and exchanges them for <fen>Money</fen> from a <fen>Buyer</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> receives the biological signal and possesses the internal experience which is a reaction to the phsyical signal.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is used for a gesture, expression, or body part indicating that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is feeling a certain urge.
<fen>State</fen> identifies the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s state of being.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> feels the biological signal. <fen>Time</fen> may also allow inference about the <fen>Reason</fen> for the biological urge.
This role identifies the  <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Experiencer</fen> feels the biological signal.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
listRoleExamples: So far, <fex>my company</fex> has sold more than three million copies.
He gave me a tired <fex>shrug</fex> and then looked down again.
She was alarmed by John's hungry <fex>state</fex>.
Nan Ho turned, <fex>his</fex> extreme agitation unnoticed by the Prince.
Liz's anger <fex>towards Raquel</fex> dates back to a charity dinner this year.
'Can I help you?' she asked, trying not to let him see the amusement <fex>in her blue eyes</fex>.
The end of the film was filled with jubilant <fex>scenes</fex>.
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.

passageCandidateSpans.text: Wow, I Can Get Sexual Too"
